para.paratext: The United States Supreme Court created the “exclusionary rule” in 1914 when it held in Weeks v. U.S.[1] that the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution barred the use of evidence secured through an illegal search and seizure in a criminal prosecution.

In Mapp v. Ohio,[2] the court applied the Fourth Amendment right to be free from unreasonable search and seizure to state action and extended the exclusionary rule to exclude evidence obtained in violation of it in both state and federal prosecutions.

Later, in U.S. v. Janis[3] the Court considered whether the exclusionary rule applies to civil cases. “This case presents an issue of the appropriateness of an extension of the judicially created exclusionary rule: Is evidence seized by a state criminal law enforcement officer in good faith, but nonetheless unconstitutionally, inadmissible in a civil proceeding by or against the United States?”[4] The Court found that the exclusionary rule was a judicially created deterrent and not a personal constitutional right and held the unconstitutionally seized evidence admissible in a civil proceeding.[5]

Again in Stone v. Powell,[6] the court reiterated that the exclusionary rule is not a personal constitutional right. “It is not calculated to redress the injury to the privacy of the victim of the search or seizure, for any ‘reparation comes too late.’ … Instead, the rule is a judicially created remedy designed to safeguard Fourth Amendment rights generally through its deterrent effect.”[7] The Janis court stated, “In the complex and turbulent history of the rule, the Court never has applied it to exclude evidence from a civil proceeding, federal or state.”[8] However, Georgia has long held that the exclusionary rule, codified at O.C.G.A. § 17-5-30, is not limited to criminal cases.[9] And both the United States Supreme Court and Georgia courts have applied the exclusionary rule to forfeiture and other quasi-criminal proceedings.[10]

Generally, discussions of “the exclusionary rule” focus on the Supreme Court's construction of the Fourth Amendment as requiring the exclusion of evidence tainted by a violation of that provision which suggests that there is only one remedial action available.[11] “This is unfortunate and misleading. … [It] ignores that exclusion may be required because evidence was obtained by violating other legal requirements, many of them not embodied in the federal constitution. Moreover, the contents of these exclusionary requirements need not necessarily be the same as that of the Fourth Amendment exclusionary requirement.”[12] Confessions excluded for violations of Miranda,[13] for instance, are exclusionary sanctions within the meaning of this section. This and the following sections focus solely upon some of these exclusionary sanctions and their underlying rules.

The scope of the exclusionary rule has changed significantly since its inception. For example, in Illinois v. Gates,[14] the Court first hinted at a move away from a strict exclusionary rule when it asked the parties, after oral argument, to address whether the exclusionary rule of Mapp should be modified so as to admit evidence obtained when the officers had a “reasonable belief” that the search warrant they executed was valid. The Court did not address that question but did overrule previous precedent by holding that the rigid “two-pronged test” applied by the Illinois court[15] for determining whether an informant's tip sufficiently establishes probable cause for issuance of a warrant should be abandoned. Instead, the Court applied a less-restrictive totality-of-the-circumstances analysis to uphold the search warrant.[16]

Later, in U.S. v. Leon,[17] the Supreme Court answered the question it left open. There, the court modified the exclusionary rule to permit the introduction of evidence obtained by officers acting in “good faith” who reasonably relied on a warrant issued by a detached and neutral magistrate even if the warrant is later found to be unsupported by probable cause. Interestingly, the Georgia Supreme Court refused to follow Leon on state law grounds.[18] Finding that infusing the Leon good faith exception into O.C.G.A. § 17-5-30 (Georgia's exclusionary rule) would be tantamount to judicial legislation, the court held that Georgia “has chosen to impose greater requirements upon its law enforcement officers than that required by the U.S. Constitution, as interpreted by the U.S. Supreme Court.”[19] The Georgia Courts have time and again declined to extend a good-faith exception in Georgia, in cases involving warrants, such as Gary, supra, and cases involving traffic stops. Abercrombie v. State, 343 Ga. App. 774, 808 S.E.2d 245 (2017).

In Nix v. Williams,[20] the United States Supreme Court further limited the exclusionary rule when it created the “inevitable discovery” rule under which evidence will be admitted if the prosecution establishes, by a preponderance of the evidence, that the information gained unlawfully would have ultimately or inevitably been discovered by lawful means. Georgia courts adopted this rule, “when the evidence in question would inevitably (or ultimately) have been discovered without reference to the police error or misconduct, the evidence is admissible.”[21]

This limitation continued in Hudson v. Michigan,[22] where court held that the exclusionary rule did not require the exclusion of evidence when there was a violation of the “knock and announce” rule. Then, the Court went further and questioned the continued vitality of the deterrence rationale of the exclusionary rule, especially in light of the defendant's ability to bring civil rights cases under 42 U.S.C.A. § 1983, which was passed 10 years after Mapp v. Ohio. Regarding the application of the exclusionary rule, the Court stated:

The exclusionary rule generates “substantial social costs,” which sometimes include setting the guilty free and the dangerous at large. We have therefore been “cautious against expanding” it, and “have repeatedly emphasized that the rule's ‘costly toll’ upon truth-seeking and law enforcement objectives presents a high obstacle for those urging [its] application,” We have rejected “[i]ndiscriminate application” of the rule, and have held it to be applicable only “where its remedial objectives are thought most efficaciously served,” … that is, “where its deterrence benefits outweigh its ‘substantial social costs[.]’”[23]

Evidence which is excluded from the case in chief may be used to impeach a defendant. Reasoning that the goals of the exclusionary rule were “adequately implemented by denying the government the use of the challenged evidence to make out its case-in-chief,”[24] the United States Supreme Court held in U.S. v. Havens[25] that a defendant's statements are subject to impeachment by evidence that has been illegally obtained and is otherwise inadmissible if he testifies to facts contrary to those in the search and seizure. The court commented that the shields provided by these exclusionary rules should not “be perverted into a license to use perjury by way of a defense, free from the risk of confrontation with prior inconsistent utterances.”[26] Georgia law has followed suit[27] with the additional requirement that when the prosecution uses this type of impeachment evidence that the court give the jury a limiting instruction that it is for impeachment purposes only.[28]

O.C.G.A. § 17-5-30 provides, in relevant part,:

A defendant aggrieved by an unlawful search and seizure may move the court … to suppress as evidence anything so obtained on the grounds that: … [t]he search and seizure with a warrant was illegal because … there was not probable cause for the issuance of the warrant …. If the motion is granted the property … shall not be admissible in evidence against the movant in any trial.
